page.title: 14HISTORY OF NAILSTONE - 1
page.content: In the original{Domesday Book}the manorial rights were held by Ernald under Hugo de Grantmesnil, one of King William's lieutenants. The estate passed to his son Ivo and then to the Count of Mewlan, later Earl of Leicester who held the land for the King. In 1235 the land was held by Henry de Hastings as tenant for the Earl of Arundel. Subsequent marriages gave the chief tenancy to the Earl of Chester with the land actually in the hands of William de Harcourt who had married Hasting's sister. The Manor remained in the Harcourt family until 1365; a present from Hastings, who retained other land in the area. The Astley family held the Manor until 1750 when it passed to Earl Howe of Gopsall. Hasting's land passed to the Earl of Kent (1571) with tenants from the Cocks,Barford and Neville families
